title: 105_s1060
content: The Act is titled the "Worldwide Tobacco Disclosure Act of 1997" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled the "Worldwide Tobacco Disclosure Act of 1997" defines a cigarette as any roll of tobacco wrapped in paper or non-tobacco substance, or in tobacco-containing substance likely to be perceived as a cigarette, and includes little cigars weighing not more than 3 pounds per 1000 units. The "Worldwide Tobacco Disclosure Act of 1997" defines a cigarette as any roll of tobacco wrapped in paper or non-tobacco substance, or in tobacco-containing substance likely to be perceived as a cigarette, and includes little cigars weighing not more than 3 pounds per 1000 units. The Act also specifies that loose rolling tobacco and papers or tubes used to contain such tobacco are included. The term "domestic concern" refers to individuals or entities with their principal place of business in the United States, while "nondiscriminatory law or regulation" refers to laws that do not discriminate. The term "nondiscriminatory law or regulation" in the "Worldwide Tobacco Disclosure Act of 1997" refers to foreign laws that treat imported goods no less favorably than domestic goods. Additionally, the definition of "package" includes any container in which tobacco products are sold, and "sale or distribution" encompasses sampling and other non-sale distributions. The term "State" includes various territories in addition to the 50 states. The term "tobacco product" includes cigarettes, little cigars, cigars, pipe tobacco, rolling tobacco, spit tobacco, and other forms of tobacco for human consumption. The term "United States" encompasses states and military installations outside of states. SEC. 3 of the law prohibits the use of funds by any US entity to negotiate the removal of foreign laws restricting tobacco products. SEC. 4 addresses cigarette export labeling. SEC. 4 of the law prohibits the export of cigarettes without proper warning labels that comply with federal requirements and are in the primary language of the intended country. The law prohibits the export of cigarettes without proper warning labels that comply with federal requirements and are in the primary language of the intended country. Labeling requirements can be waived for cigarettes exported to specific countries for consumption. The law prohibits exporting cigarettes without compliant warning labels in the primary language of the destination country. A list of countries with similar or stricter labeling requirements will be published by the President within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The President will update a list of countries with labeling requirements, adding or removing countries based on compliance. Any violation of these provisions will result in penalties, including fines. Penalties for violating subsection (a) include fines of up to $100,000 per day, or up to $150,000 per day for knowingly reexporting or transshipping cigarettes through certain countries. District courts can issue injunctions to prevent violations. Section 12 of the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is repealed. Regulatory authority must be established within 90 days. The President must establish regulatory authority within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The provisions of subsections (a) through (c) will take effect upon the regulations' effective date.
